title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. Unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code, specifically included in gross income by reason of debt discharge. These payments must be applicable child support payments required under a support instrument for the taxpayer's child. The Internal Revenue Code requires eligible taxpayers to send a notice to individuals who failed to make child support payments, informing them to include the amount in gross income. The Internal Revenue Code mandates eligible taxpayers to notify individuals who have not paid child support to include the amount in their gross income for the previous taxable year. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send the notice if the address is available. If there is no known address, no income needs to be included for any taxable year before the year preceding the year in which the notice can be sent. The amendments made by this section require subsequent child support payments to be included in gross income and then allowed as a deduction in the year of payment. Definitions for 'applicable child support payments' and 'eligible taxpayer' are provided in section 166(f). These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments remaining at the end of the taxable year for eligible taxpayers. The deduction is equal to the amount of such payments, with limitations per child. The deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers is limited to $10,000 per child. An eligible taxpayer is defined as an individual with an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000, unpaid child support of $500 or more, and meeting identification requirements. The term "applicable child support payment" refers to payments due in a taxable year. The deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers is limited to $10,000 per child. An eligible taxpayer is defined as an individual with an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000, unpaid child support of $500 or more, and meeting identification requirements. The term "applicable child support payment" refers to payments due in a taxable year, including periodic fixed amounts or payments for medical, educational expenses, insurance premiums, or similar items required by a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. A qualifying child is defined as a child of an eligible individual for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151 for the taxable year. The deduction for unpaid child support payments is limited to $10,000 per child for eligible taxpayers with an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000. Payments must be delinquent for at least a year, and half of the required payments to the eligible taxpayer during the 12-month period must be paid to avoid being treated as unpaid child support. Coordination with TANF is also considered. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under the Social Security Act. Identification requirements include providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child and the individual responsible for child support payments on the tax return claiming the deduction. "In cases where information is not provided, the eligible taxpayer can certify that the information is unknown. Cost-of-living adjustments increase certain dollar amounts for taxable years after 2000. Subsequent payments are also addressed." Subsequent payments made after a deduction was allowed must be included in the eligible taxpayer's gross income for the year. This rule does not apply if the right to receive the payment has been assigned to a State. A support instrument, such as a divorce decree or separation agreement, must meet specific requirements for this subsection. The text discusses amendments to the tax code regarding unpaid child support payments. It includes provisions for deductions for nonitemizers and defines applicable child support payments. The amendments made by this section have a specified effective date. The amendments made by this section regarding unpaid child support payments have an effective date after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will solely retire US public debt, not for other purposes, regardless of other laws.
